The Fort Ellice Treaty. 125

SHAPONETUNG’s Fmsr SON—“ I ﬁnd what was done at Qu’Appelle was good, does it take in all my children ’3”

Line's-Gov. Monms—“ Yes.”

SHAPONETUNo’s Fmsr SON—“ I thank you for coming and bringing what is good for our children.”

Linux-Gov. MORRIS—“ I forgot to say that we will be able to give you a small present, some powder and shot, blankets and calicoes. Each band must have a Chief and four headmen, but you are not all here to—day. I wart to—day to know the Chief and two headmen.

“Now I want to know will you take my hand and what is in it.”

The Indians came up and shook hands in token of acceptance.

Llama-Gov. MORRIs—“ I am glad to shake hands with you ; the white man and the red man have shaken' hands and are friends. You must be good subjects to the Queen and obey her laws.”

The Indians introduced as their Chief, Way-wa-se-ca-pow; and as their headmen, Ota-ma—koo-euin and Shaponetung’s ﬁrst son.

His Honor then explained the memorandum to them, when it was signed.
